citation.article-title: Flavobacterium frigidimaris sp. nov., isolated from Antarctic seawater.

p.s: Description of Flavobacterium frigidimaris sp. nov.
Flavobacterium frigidimaris (fri.gid.i.ma.r'is. L. adj. frigidus, cold; L. -a, -um, n. mare –is the sea; N.L. gen. n. frigidimaris, of a cold sea)
The strain is a Gram-negative, rods (0.6–0.8 μm in width and 1.5–2.0 μm in length), non-sporulating, and non-flagellated bacterium, and shows a gliding motility on fresh, nutrient-poor medium.
Colonies on trypticase soy agar are circular and low convex with bright orange-yellow color.
The growth temperature range is between 2°C and 26°C: no growth is observed at 30°C.
Growth is well on the Trypticase soy agar and NaCl-containing medium (up to 3%).
The catalase and cytochrome oxidase test are positive and negative, respectively, and the strain does not reduce nitrate to nitrite, but nitrite is reduced.
ONPG is hydrolyzed and the degradation of gelatin, casein, starch, pectin, chitin, and aesculin occurs.
CM-cellulose and agar are not degraded.
The strain is aerobic and chemoheterotrophic.
Acids are produced from arabinose, cellobiose, fructose, galactose, glucose, maltose, mannitol, mannose, raffinose, sucrose, trehalose and xylose.
No acid occurs from glycerol, inositol, lactose, rhamnose and sorbitol.
The major component of the isoprenoid quinone is MK-6.
Whole cell contains a wide range of saturated, branched, monounsaturated and 3-OH fatty acids, but are dominated by iso-C15:1, iso-C15:0, C15:0, C16:1 and 3-OH iso-C15:0.
The G+C content of the DNA is about 34.5 mol%.
The type strain KUC-1 (JCM 12218T = DSM 15937T) were isolated from the Antarctic seawater.
